Intervention: • Accelerating partial breast irradiation: Accubost APBI 34.0 Gy in 10 fractions
Enlarged up to 5 years of follow-up - Rhode Island Hospital only
The follow-up was extended to include follow-up visits to 2.6 weeks and 4.6.12.18.24 months, and each year (+/- 6 months) for an additional 3 years for a total of about 5 years of follow-up.
Eligibility: A confirmed histological diagnosis of invasive breast carcinoma or DCIS
Age greater than or equal to 50 years
Treatment with breast conservation surgery with axillary dissection or sentinel biopsy of lymph nodes
- Pathological tumour size of 2 cm or less
Invasive ductal, mucous, tubular or colloidal histology
- Positive estrogen receptor for invasive carcinoma.
- Negative surgical margins greater than or equal to 2 mm
• Known number BRCA 1/2 Mutation; (BRCA 1 and 2 tests are not required)
A psychiatric or addictive disorder that would prevent participation in follow-up
(unless biopsy has proven to be benign)
Lobular characteristics of histology (pure or mixed) or histology of sarcoma
A positive node on the axillary dissection or in the sentinel biopsy of the ganglion;
The lumpectomy cavity is not well visualized on AccuBoost imaging
The lumpectomy cavity with a margin of 1cm (PTV) is not sufficiently covered by an applicator (PTV > 6cm)
• Superposition of the skin between the orthogonal treatment axes.
Results: Any radiological treatment toxicity will be noted and noted using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events of the National Cancer Institute (NCI) v3.0 (Appendix 4). Acute side effects are all side effects occurring within 3 months of treatment. Intermediate side effects are all side effects occurring between 3 months and 2 years.
Description of the arm/group: AccuBoost APBI- 34.0 Gy in 10fx
• Accelerating partial breast irradiation: Accubost APBI 34.0 Gy in 10 fractions
Title of the arm/group: Extended to 5 years of follow-up-Rhode Island Hospital Only
The follow-up was extended to include follow-up visits to 2.6 weeks and 4.6.12.18.24 months, and each year (+/- 6 months) for an additional 3 years for a total of approximately 5 years of follow-up.
